018package org.opengis.filter;
019
020import java.util.List;
021import java.util.Collections;
022import org.opengis.util.ScopedName;
023import org.opengis.feature.Feature;
024import org.opengis.annotation.UML;
025
026import static org.opengis.annotation.Specification.ISO_19143;
027
028
029/**
030 * Expression whose value is computed by retrieving the value indicated by a name in a resource.
031 * {@code ValueReference} can used to specify the name of any property of an object whose value
032 * shall be tested by a predicate in a filter expression.
033 * The most common application of this is to retrieve a {@linkplain Feature feature}'s property
034 * using a property name or an XPath expression.
035 *
036 * @author  Chris Dillard (SYS Technologies)
037 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
038 * @version 3.1
039 *
040 * @param  <R>  the type of resources (e.g. {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}) used as inputs.
041 * @param  <V>  the type of values fetched by the expression.
042 *
043 * @since 3.1
044 */
045@UML(identifier="ValueReference", specification=ISO_19143)
046public interface ValueReference<R,V> extends Expression<R,V> {
047    /**
048     * Returns the name of the value reference function.
049     * The default implementation returns {@code "fes:ValueReference"}.
050     *
051     * @return {@code "ValueReference"} in a scope at implementation choice.
052     */
053    @Override
054    default ScopedName getFunctionName() {
055        return Name.VALUE_REFERENCE;
056    }
057
058    /**
059     * Returns an empty list since value references have no parameters.
060     *
061     * @return an empty list.
062     */
063    @Override
064    default List<Expression<R,?>> getParameters() {
065        return Collections.emptyList();
066    }
067
068    /**
069     * Returns the path to the property whose value will be returned by the {@code apply(R)} method.
070     * If all characters are {@linkplain Character#isUnicodeIdentifierPart(int) Unicode identifier part},
071     * then the XPath expression is simply a property name. Otherwise
072     * (i.e. if the returned path contains characters such as {@code `:`}, {@code `/`} or {@code '['}),
073     * the returned string uses a simplified form of the XPath query language described below.
074     *
075     * <h4>XPath syntax</h4>
076     * The path is relative to the resource element (e.g. the {@link Feature}), except in the case of
077     * a join operation, in which case the path is relative to the parent of the resource element.
078     * The following set of XPath rules shall be supported:
079     *
080     * <ul class="verbose">
081     *   <li>Abbreviated form of the child axis specifier (i.e. the default form with no specifier).</li>
082     *   <li>Abbreviated form of the attribute axis specifier (i.e. the {@code '@'} character).</li>
083     *   <li>Predicate with a positive non-zero integer to indicate which child of the context node should be selected.</li>
084     *   <li>Predicate of the form {@code "child=value"} to identify a specific object property
085     *       by constraining the child elements of the property.</li>
086     * </ul>
087     *
088     * <div class="note"><b>Example:</b>
089     * {@code addresses[street="Oxfordstrasse"]/number}
090     * </div>
091     *
092     * Implementations may support a larger set of XPath rules if desired.
093     *
094     * @return path to the property whose value will be returned by the {@code apply(R)} method.
095     *
096     * @see Feature#getPropertyValue(String)
097     */
098    String getXPath();
099}
